**Hugo Wallace Weaving** (born 4 April 1960) is an [English-
Australian](/wiki/English_Australians "English Australians")[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] film
and stage actor. He is best known for playing [Agent Smith](/wiki/Agent_Smith
"Agent Smith") in _[The Matrix](/wiki/The_Matrix_trilogy "The Matrix
trilogy")_ trilogy (1999–2003), [Elrond](/wiki/Elrond "Elrond") in _[The Lord
of the Rings](/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings_\(film_series\) "The Lord of the
Rings \(film series\)")_ (2001–2003) and _[The
Hobbit](/wiki/The_Hobbit_\(film_series\) "The Hobbit \(film series\)")_
(2012–2014) film trilogies, [V](/wiki/V_\(comics\) "V \(comics\)") in _[V for
Vendetta](/wiki/V_for_Vendetta_\(film\) "V for Vendetta \(film\)")_ (2006),
[Red Skull](/wiki/Red_Skull "Red Skull") in _[Captain America: The First
Avenger](/wiki/Captain_America:_The_First_Avenger "Captain America: The First
Avenger")_ and the father in _[Hacksaw Ridge](/wiki/Hacksaw_Ridge "Hacksaw
Ridge")_. Weaving's first television role was in the 1984 Australian
television series _[Bodyline](/wiki/Bodyline_\(miniseries\) "Bodyline
\(miniseries\)")_ , where he portrayed [English](/wiki/England_cricket_team
"England cricket team") cricket captain [Douglas
Jardine](/wiki/Douglas_Jardine "Douglas Jardine"). In film, he first rose to
prominence for his performance as Martin in the Australian drama
[_Proof_](/wiki/Proof_\(1991_film\) "Proof \(1991 film\)") (1991). Weaving
played Anthony "Tick" Belrose/Mitzi Del Bra in the comedy-drama _[The
Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the
Desert](/wiki/The_Adventures_of_Priscilla,_Queen_of_the_Desert "The Adventures
of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert")_ (1994); and multiple roles in the science
fiction film _[Cloud Atlas](/wiki/Cloud_Atlas_\(film\) "Cloud Atlas
\(film\)")_ (2012). His roles as a [voice actor](/wiki/Voice_acting "Voice
acting") include Rex in _[Babe](/wiki/Babe_\(film\) "Babe \(film\)")_ , Noah
in _[Happy Feet](/wiki/Happy_Feet "Happy Feet")_ and _[Happy Feet
Two](/wiki/Happy_Feet_Two "Happy Feet Two")_ , and [Megatron](/wiki/Megatron
"Megatron") in the _[Transformers](/wiki/Transformers_\(film_series\)
"Transformers \(film series\)")_ film series.

Weaving's awards for acting include a [Satellite Award](/wiki/Satellite_Award
"Satellite Award"), [MTV Movie Award](/wiki/MTV_Movie_Award "MTV Movie Award")
and six [Australian Film Institute Awards](/wiki/Australian_Film_Institute
"Australian Film Institute").

## Early
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hugo_Weaving&action=edit&section=1&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Early life")]

Weaving was born at the [University of Ibadan Teaching
Hospital](/wiki/University_College_Hospital,_Ibadan "University College
Hospital, Ibadan"), in [Ibadan](/wiki/Ibadan "Ibadan"), in the [Colony and
Protectorate of Nigeria](/wiki/Colony_and_Protectorate_of_Nigeria "Colony and
Protectorate of Nigeria"), to English parents Anne (née Lennard) (born 1932),
a tour guide and former teacher, and Wallace Weaving (born 1929), a
[seismologist](/wiki/Seismologist "Seismologist").[1][2][3] His maternal
grandmother was Belgian.[3] A year after his birth, his family returned to
England, living in [Bedford](/wiki/Bedford "Bedford") and
[Brighton](/wiki/Brighton "Brighton") before moving to
[Melbourne](/wiki/Melbourne "Melbourne") and [Sydney](/wiki/Sydney "Sydney")
in Australia; [Johannesburg](/wiki/Johannesburg "Johannesburg") in South
Africa; and then returning to England again.[1] While in England, he attended
[The Downs School](/wiki/Charlton_House,_Wraxall "Charlton House, Wraxall"),
[Wraxall](/wiki/Wraxall,_Somerset "Wraxall, Somerset"), near
[Bristol](/wiki/Bristol "Bristol"), and [Queen Elizabeth's
Hospital](/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth%27s_Hospital "Queen Elizabeth's Hospital").
While at the Downs School, in 1973 Weaving played one of his first theatrical
roles, taking the part of 'Captain Asquith' in [Robert Bolt](/wiki/Robert_Bolt
"Robert Bolt")'s "The Thwarting of Baron Bolligrew". His family moved back to
Australia in 1976, where he attended [Knox Grammar
School](/wiki/Knox_Grammar_School "Knox Grammar School") in Sydney. He
graduated from Sydney's [National Institute of Dramatic
Art](/wiki/National_Institute_of_Dramatic_Art "National Institute of Dramatic
Art") in 1981.

##
Career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hugo_Weaving&action=edit&section=2&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Career")]

###
1984–1998[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hugo_Weaving&action=edit&section=3&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: 1984–1998")]

Weaving's first television role was in the 1984 Australian television series
_[Bodyline](/wiki/Bodyline_\(miniseries\) "Bodyline \(miniseries\)")_ , as the
[English](/wiki/England_cricket_team "England cricket team") cricket captain
[Douglas Jardine](/wiki/Douglas_Jardine "Douglas Jardine"). Weaving appeared
in the Australian miniseries _[The Dirtwater
Dynasty](/wiki/The_Dirtwater_Dynasty "The Dirtwater Dynasty")_ in 1988 and as
[Geoffrey Chambers](/wiki/Geoffrey_Chambers "Geoffrey Chambers") in the drama
_[Barlow and Chambers: A Long Way From Home](/wiki/Dadah_is_Death "Dadah is
Death")_. He starred opposite Nicole Kidman in the 1989 film _[Bangkok
Hilton](/wiki/Bangkok_Hilton "Bangkok Hilton")_. In 1991, Weaving received the
[Australian Film Institute](/wiki/Australian_Film_Institute "Australian Film
Institute")'s "Best Actor" award for his performance in the low-budget
_[Proof](/wiki/Proof_\(1991_film\) "Proof \(1991 film\)")_. He appeared as Sir
John in the 1993 [Yahoo Serious](/wiki/Yahoo_Serious "Yahoo Serious") comedy
_[Reckless Kelly](/wiki/Reckless_Kelly "Reckless Kelly")_ , a lampoon of
Australian outlaw [Ned Kelly](/wiki/Ned_Kelly "Ned Kelly").

In the mid-90s, Weaving portrayed [drag queen](/wiki/Drag_queen "Drag queen")
Anthony "Tick" Belrose/Mitzi Del Bra in the 1994 film _[Priscilla, Queen of
the Desert](/wiki/The_Adventures_of_Priscilla,_Queen_of_the_Desert "The
Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert")_ , and provided the voice of
Rex the sheepdog in the 1995 family film _[Babe](/wiki/Babe_\(film\) "Babe
\(film\)")_. In 1998, he received the "Best Actor" award from the [Montreal
Film Festival](/wiki/Montreal_Film_Festival "Montreal Film Festival") for his
performance as a suspected [serial killer](/wiki/Serial_killer "Serial
killer") in _[The Interview](/wiki/The_Interview_\(1998_film\) "The Interview
\(1998 film\)")_.

###
1999–2010[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hugo_Weaving&action=edit&section=4&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: 1999–2010")]

Weaving played the enigmatic and evil-minded [Agent Smith](/wiki/Agent_Smith
"Agent Smith") in the 1999 film _[The Matrix](/wiki/The_Matrix "The Matrix")_.
He later reprised that role in the film's 2003 sequels, _[The Matrix
Reloaded](/wiki/The_Matrix_Reloaded "The Matrix Reloaded")_ and _[The Matrix
Revolutions](/wiki/The_Matrix_Revolutions "The Matrix Revolutions")_. He was a
voice actor in the cartoon film _[The Magic
Pudding](/wiki/The_Magic_Pudding_\(film\) "The Magic Pudding \(film\)")_.[4]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Hugo_Weaving.jpg/170px-
Hugo_Weaving.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hugo_Weaving.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hugo_Weaving.jpg "Enlarge")

Weaving at _[The Matrix Revolutions](/wiki/The_Matrix_Revolutions "The Matrix
Revolutions")_ premiere, November 2003

He garnered additional acclaim in the role of half-elven lord
[Elrond](/wiki/Elrond "Elrond") in [Peter Jackson](/wiki/Peter_Jackson "Peter
Jackson")'s three-film adaptation of _[The Lord of the
Rings](/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings "The Lord of the Rings")_ , released
between 2001 and 2003. Weaving was the main actor in Andrew Kotatko's award-
winning film _[Everything Goes](/wiki/Everything_Goes_\(film\) "Everything
Goes \(film\)")_ (2004). He starred as a heroin-addicted ex-[rugby
league](/wiki/Rugby_league "Rugby league") player in the 2005 Australian indie
film _[Little Fish](/wiki/Little_Fish_\(film\) "Little Fish \(film\)")_ ,
opposite [Cate Blanchett](/wiki/Cate_Blanchett "Cate Blanchett"). Weaving
played the title role as [V](/wiki/V_\(comics\) "V \(comics\)") in the 2006
film _[V for Vendetta](/wiki/V_for_Vendetta_\(film\) "V for Vendetta
\(film\)")_ , in which he was reunited with the [Wachowskis](/wiki/Wachowskis
"Wachowskis"), creators of _The Matrix_ trilogy, who wrote the adapted
screenplay. Actor [James Purefoy](/wiki/James_Purefoy "James Purefoy") was
originally signed to play the role, but was fired six weeks into filming over
creative differences.[5][6][7] Weaving reshot most of James Purefoy's scenes
as V (even though his face is never seen) apart from a couple of minor
dialogue-free scenes early in the film. Stuntman David Leitch performed all of
V's stunts.

Weaving reprised his role as Elrond for the video game _[The Lord of the
Rings: The Battle for Middle-Earth
II](/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Battle_for_Middle-Earth_II "The Lord of
the Rings: The Battle for Middle-Earth II")_. He regularly appears in
productions by the [Sydney Theatre Company](/wiki/Sydney_Theatre_Company
"Sydney Theatre Company") (STC). In 2006, he worked with Cate Blanchett on a
reprise of the STC production of _[Hedda Gabler](/wiki/Hedda_Gabler "Hedda
Gabler")_ in New York City. In a controversial move by director [Michael
Bay](/wiki/Michael_Bay "Michael Bay"), Weaving was chosen as the
[Decepticon](/wiki/Decepticon "Decepticon") leader
[Megatron](/wiki/Megatron_\(Transformers\)#Transformers "Megatron
\(Transformers\)") vocally in the 2007 live-action film
_[Transformers](/wiki/Transformers_\(film\) "Transformers \(film\)")_ , rather
than using the [original version of the
character](/wiki/Megatron_\(Transformers\) "Megatron \(Transformers\)")'s
voice created by the voice actor, [Frank Welker](/wiki/Frank_Welker "Frank
Welker").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Hugo_w_%28cropped%29.jpg/170px-
Hugo_w_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hugo_w_\(cropped\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hugo_w_\(cropped\).jpg "Enlarge")

Weaving at _[The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the
King](/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Return_of_the_King "The Lord of the
Rings: The Return of the King")_ premiere, December 2003

Weaving himself was unaware of the controversy and had accepted the role based
on Michael Bay's personal request; in a November 2008 _Sun Herald_ interview,
he said he'd never seen _Transformers_. Though Weaving reprised his role in
two sequels, he does not have much personal investment in the _Transformers_
films. In February 2010, Weaving revealed to _[The Age](/wiki/The_Age "The
Age")_ : "Director Michael Bay talks to me on the phone. I've never met him.
We were doing the voice for the second one and I still hadn't seen the first
one. I still didn't really know who the characters were and I didn't know what
anything was. It's a voice job, for sure, and people assume I've spent my life
working on it, but I really know so little about it."[8] In 2012, Weaving said
to _[Collider](/wiki/Collider_\(website\) "Collider \(website\)")_ : "It was
one of the only things I've ever done where I had no knowledge of it, I didn't
care about it, I didn't think about it. They wanted me to do it. In one way, I
regret that bit. I don't regret doing it, but I very rarely do something if
it's meaningless. It was meaningless to me, honestly. I don't mean that in any
nasty way."

Weaving played a supporting role in [Joe Johnston](/wiki/Joe_Johnston "Joe
Johnston")'s 2010 remake of the 1941 film _[The
Wolfman](/wiki/The_Wolfman_\(2010_film\) "The Wolfman \(2010 film\)")_ ,
starring [Benicio del Toro](/wiki/Benicio_del_Toro "Benicio del Toro").
Immediately after _Wolfman_ wrapped in spring 2008, he returned home to
Australia to film a lead role in the film _[Last
Ride](/wiki/Last_Ride_\(film\) "Last Ride \(film\)")_ , directed by Glendyn
Ivin. In early 2009, [Guillermo Del Toro](/wiki/Guillermo_Del_Toro "Guillermo
Del Toro"), then director of [_The Hobbit_
films](/wiki/The_Hobbit_\(film_series\) "The Hobbit \(film series\)"),
prequels to _The Lord of the Rings_ , confirmed his intent to again cast
Weaving as [Elrond](/wiki/Elrond "Elrond") of [Rivendell](/wiki/Rivendell
"Rivendell") in a BBC interview.[9] When asked about reprising the role,
Weaving replied that he was game, but had not officially been approached. Del
Toro eventually left the project; Peter Jackson decided to direct the films
himself but Weaving was not officially confirmed in the cast until May 2011.

Weaving spent the summer of 2009 starring in the [Melbourne Theatre
Company](/wiki/Melbourne_Theatre_Company "Melbourne Theatre Company")'s
production of _[God of Carnage](/wiki/God_of_Carnage "God of Carnage")_ ,
portraying the caustic lawyer Alain Reille. He returned to the stage in
November 2010 in Sydney Theatre Company's _[Uncle Vanya](/wiki/Uncle_Vanya
"Uncle Vanya")_ , co-starring Cate Blanchett and [Richard
Roxburgh](/wiki/Richard_Roxburgh "Richard Roxburgh").[10] Weaving filmed a
guest role on Roxburgh's Australian TV series
_[Rake](/wiki/Rake_\(2010_TV_series\) "Rake \(2010 TV series\)")_ in May 2010.

In May 2009, Weaving accepted a co-starring role in the docudrama _[Oranges
and Sunshine](/wiki/Oranges_and_Sunshine "Oranges and Sunshine")_ ,[11] about
the forced migration of thousands of British children to Australia in the
1950s. Filming began in autumn 2009 in [Nottingham](/wiki/Nottingham
"Nottingham"), England and [Adelaide](/wiki/Adelaide "Adelaide"), South
Australia and continued through January 2010. The film premiered at the [Rome
International Film Festival](/wiki/Rome_International_Film_Festival "Rome
International Film Festival") on 28 October 2010 and garnered positive
reviews. 2010 also saw the release of _[Legend of the
Guardians](/wiki/Legend_of_the_Guardians:_The_Owls_of_Ga%27Hoole "Legend of
the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole")_ (formerly _The Guardians of Ga
'Hoole_), in which Weaving has another high-profile voice role,[12] portraying
two different owls named Noctus and Grimble in [Zack Snyder](/wiki/Zack_Snyder
"Zack Snyder")'s film adaptation of [Kathryn Lasky](/wiki/Kathryn_Lasky
"Kathryn Lasky")'s popular series of children's books.

On 4 May 2010, it was officially confirmed by [Marvel
Studios](/wiki/Marvel_Studios "Marvel Studios") that Weaving would play the
fictional [Nazi](/wiki/Nazi "Nazi") the [Red Skull](/wiki/Red_Skull "Red
Skull") in the superhero film _[Captain America: The First
Avenger](/wiki/Captain_America:_The_First_Avenger "Captain America: The First
Avenger")_.[13] Weaving completed filming his role on the project in September
2010 and returned to Sydney to prepare for _Uncle Vanya_. It is unlikely he
will sign on for any further installments in the [Marvel Cinematic
Universe](/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe "Marvel Cinematic Universe"); in an
August 2011 _[Baltimore Sun](/wiki/Baltimore_Sun "Baltimore Sun")_ interview,
the actor confided he's weary of typecasting and of "blockbuster" films in
general: "I think I've about had enough...I'm not sure how many more of them
I'll make. It doesn't feel to me as though they've been the majority of my
work, though that's probably the way it seems to most other people.".[14]

###
2011–present[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hugo_Weaving&action=edit&section=5&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: 2011–present")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Hugo_Weaving_%288957650533%29.jpg/220px-
Hugo_Weaving_%288957650533%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hugo_Weaving_\(8957650533\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hugo_Weaving_\(8957650533\).jpg "Enlarge")

Weaving at [Sydney Film Festival](/wiki/Sydney_Film_Festival "Sydney Film
Festival"), 2013

On 13 March 2011, _The Key Man_ , which Weaving filmed in 2006, finally
debuted at the [South By Southwest](/wiki/South_By_Southwest "South By
Southwest") Festival in [Austin, Texas](/wiki/Austin,_Texas "Austin,
Texas").[15] The child migrant saga _[Oranges and
Sunshine](/wiki/Oranges_and_Sunshine "Oranges and Sunshine")_ opened in the UK
on 1 April, the culmination of months of success on the festival circuit in
late 2010-early 2011.[16] In March, the [Sydney Theatre
Company](/wiki/Sydney_Theatre_Company "Sydney Theatre Company") and [John F.
Kennedy Center for the Performing
Arts](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_Center_for_the_Performing_Arts "John F. Kennedy
Center for the Performing Arts") announced that STC's 2010 production of
Chekhov's [Uncle Vanya](/wiki/Uncle_Vanya "Uncle Vanya") would be reprised in
Washington, D.C. during the month of August[17] In April, months of
speculation finally ended when Weaving appeared on [_The
Hobbit_](/wiki/The_Hobbit_\(film_series\) "The Hobbit \(film series\)")'s New
Zealand set, shortly before a production spokesman officially confirmed the
actor's return as Elrond in Peter Jackson's prequel trilogy to _The Lord of
the Rings_.[18] He was part of the cast of the Wachowskis' adaptation of
[David Mitchell](/wiki/David_Mitchell_\(author\) "David Mitchell
\(author\)")'s novel _[Cloud Atlas](/wiki/Cloud_Atlas_\(novel\) "Cloud Atlas
\(novel\)")_.[19] The project, co-starring [Tom Hanks](/wiki/Tom_Hanks "Tom
Hanks"), [Ben Whishaw](/wiki/Ben_Whishaw "Ben Whishaw"), [Halle
Berry](/wiki/Halle_Berry "Halle Berry"), [Jim Broadbent](/wiki/Jim_Broadbent
"Jim Broadbent"), and [Susan Sarandon](/wiki/Susan_Sarandon "Susan Sarandon"),
began filming in September 2011 and was released in October 2012.

2012 also found Weaving re-focusing on his theatrical career, with a return to
the Sydney Theatre Company to star in a new adaptation of [Christopher
Hampton](/wiki/Christopher_Hampton "Christopher Hampton")'s play _[Les
Liaisons Dangereuses](/wiki/Les_Liaisons_Dangereuses "Les Liaisons
Dangereuses")_ in March.[20] He portrayed the notorious Vicomte de Valmont, a
character he first played onstage in 1987. His frequent stage foil [Pamela
Rabe](/wiki/Pamela_Rabe "Pamela Rabe") costarred. Weaving and [Cate
Blanchett](/wiki/Cate_Blanchett "Cate Blanchett") reprised their roles in
STC's internationally lauded production of _Uncle Vanya_ for a ten-day run at
[New York's](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") [Lincoln
Center](/wiki/Lincoln_Center "Lincoln Center") in July.[21]

The busy actor also joined the cast of three forthcoming Australian films in
summer 2012. The Western-tinged police thriller _[Mystery
Road](/wiki/Mystery_Road "Mystery Road")_ , written and directed by [Ivan
Sen](/wiki/Ivan_Sen "Ivan Sen"), began filming in June 2012.[22] Weaving is
also scheduled to star in the prison drama _[Healing](/wiki/Healing_\(film\)
"Healing \(film\)")_ for director Craig Monahan, with whom he previously made
_The Interview_ (1998) and _Peaches_ (2005).[23] He appeared in a segment of
the Australian anthology film _[The Turning](/wiki/The_Turning_\(2013_film\)
"The Turning \(2013 film\)")_ , based on [Tim Winton](/wiki/Tim_Winton "Tim
Winton")'s collection of linked stories, entitled "The Commission", directed
by [David Wenham](/wiki/David_Wenham "David Wenham").[24] He ended 2013 co-
starring with [Richard Roxburgh](/wiki/Richard_Roxburgh "Richard Roxburgh")
and [Philip Quast](/wiki/Philip_Quast "Philip Quast") in [Samuel
Beckett](/wiki/Samuel_Beckett "Samuel Beckett")'s _[Waiting For
Godot](/wiki/Waiting_For_Godot "Waiting For Godot")_ , for the Sydney Theatre
Company.[25][26]

In the spring of 2013, Weaving reprised the [Agent Smith](/wiki/Agent_Smith
"Agent Smith") role for a [General Electric](/wiki/General_Electric "General
Electric") television commercial for their "Brilliant Machines" innovations in
healthcare management technology, which was slated to air during a break from
13 April's edition of _[Saturday Night Live](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live
"Saturday Night Live")_ , and subsequently continued to receive multiple
airings on major cable networks.[27]

From 26 July to 27 September 2014, Weaving played the titular role of [Sydney
Theatre Company](/wiki/Sydney_Theatre_Company "Sydney Theatre Company")'s
production of _[Macbeth](/wiki/Macbeth "Macbeth")_.[28] In an unusual
treatment of the Shakespearian tragedy by young Sydney director [Kip
Williams](/wiki/Kip_Williams "Kip Williams"), Weaving's performance was
described by Peter Gotting of _The Guardian_ as "the role of his career".[29]

In October 2015, Weaving joined the cast of the film adaption of [Craig
Silvey](/wiki/Craig_Silvey "Craig Silvey")'s Australian novel, _[Jasper
Jones](/wiki/Jasper_Jones "Jasper Jones")_.[30][31]

## Personal
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hugo_Weaving&action=edit&section=6&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Personal life")]

When he was 13 years old, Weaving was diagnosed with [epilepsy](/wiki/Epilepsy
"Epilepsy").[32] He has been with his longtime girlfriend Katrina Greenwood
since 1984;[33] the two live in Sydney and have two children together, Harry
(b. 1989) and Holly (b. 1993). Harry is an actor who uses the stage name Harry
Greenwood.[34] Hugo also has a brother, Simon, and a sister, Anna Jane. His
niece, [Samara Weaving](/wiki/Samara_Weaving "Samara Weaving"), portrayed
[Indigo Walker](/wiki/Indigo_Walker "Indigo Walker") on the long-running
Australian soap, _[Home and Away](/wiki/Home_and_Away "Home and Away")_ , and
her younger sister Morgan joined the cast as Lottie Ryan.[35] In 2004, Weaving
became an ambassador for Australian [animal rights](/wiki/Animal_rights
"Animal rights") organisation [Voiceless, the animal protection
institute](/wiki/Voiceless,_the_animal_protection_institute "Voiceless, the
animal protection institute"). He attends events, promotes Voiceless in
interviews, and assists in their judging of annual grants recipients.[36]
